bullets.text: U.S. push to acquire Greenland strains NATO ties; Denmark sends extra troops as Greenland warns to prepare for “everything,” not ruling out U.S. military action.
Greenland rhetoric and tariff threats triggered a risk-off move: biggest U.S. stock drop in months, Asia followed; “Sell America” trade resurfaces.
Dollar and Treasurys slid while gold spiked as investors fled U.S. assets, highlighting sensitivity of funding costs to geopolitical shocks.
Danish pension fund plans to sell $100M of U.S. Treasurys, citing weak U.S. fiscal outlook—an early signal of foreign demand risk for U.S. debt.
Supreme Court tariff ruling could constrain Greenland-linked tariff threats; administration may delay refund timing, prolonging uncertainty for importers and supply chains.
Amazon says tariffs are starting to “creep” into consumer prices, reinforcing inflation pass-through risk even as demand slows.
Fed governance risk rises: Treasury’s Bessent says next Fed chair pick could come next week; Powell could remain a governor even if removed as chair.
Netflix narrowly beat earnings and reached 325M subscribers; product moves (redesign, live voting) aim to boost daily engagement versus social platforms.
United Airlines results support a loyalty-and-perks strategy; guidance suggests potential record earnings after a strong start to 2026.
AI economics shift: Nadella says energy costs will determine AI winners; firms warn automation could hit labor markets “like a tsunami,” raising layoff and retraining pressures.
AI safety and governance tighten: OpenAI rolls out age prediction; Benioff urges regulation as models show harmful behaviors, increasing compliance burdens for consumer AI.
Scientists camp on Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier to improve melt forecasts; better data could reprice long-run coastal risk and infrastructure costs via sea-level projections.
Biomedicine advances: researchers solved a key bottleneck in cancer cell therapy manufacturing, potentially expanding scalable, personalized treatments and biotech investment opportunities.
Security research flags weaknesses: quantum computers may have exploitable flaws, underscoring urgency of post-quantum cryptography planning and realistic threat modeling.
